speaker: grahampaige
content: Welcome everyone. Let's begin discussion on: Agenda Item No. 3.3: Technology Plan - The board will review a proposal to expand digital learning access by providing Chromebooks to every high school student. This initiative is estimated to cost $10,000 annually for devices, maintenance, and licensing. The program is designed to ensure equitable access to technology, support blended learning, and prepare students with digital skills for college and career readiness.. Who would like to start?

speaker: kateacuff
content: I'll go ahead and start. As you know, we've been talking about this for some time now, and I'm very excited to finally see it come before us. In my opinion, our district should be commended for taking steps towards closing the equity gap when it comes to digital accessibility. Providing these devices can really help level the playing field for those students who may not have reliable internet at home.

speaker: ellenosborne
content: I agree with Kate, this is a significant step forward in addressing the digital divide. However, I do have some concerns regarding the sustainability of this plan. How do we plan to fund this initiative beyond the first year? Have we explored any opportunities for grants or partnerships that could offset some of the costs?

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: So if there was no follow-up questions or comments from Ms. Osborne. We also had some conversations around digital citizenship which will need to continue, but one thing I didn't hear mentioned so far has been parental involvement, how do they figure into all of this? Are they supposed to monitor their kids' usage outside of class hours? And then two other things, do the teachers have training on effectively utilizing them, because just having them doesn't mean anything if people don't use them properly.

speaker: davidoberg
content: I think Katrina makes a valid point about teacher training. I understand that money isn't going to magically appear out of thin air. If this is something we truly believe is necessary, though, shouldn't we find ways to reallocate resources within the budget to make sure it happens instead of relying solely on seeking external funding sources?

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: Mr. Oberg, I completely agree with your sentiments. My mind keeps going back to what we heard during the presentation of course, the superintendent did say he's open to considering rearranging priorities if the board expressed interest in doing so, but I guess I'm more concerned than ever about being realistic about where the funds will come from long-term. Is there an option B that we haven't considered yet. What exactly does that look like in terms of rearrangement of current budgets? Has administration even begun crunching numbers for potential adjustments? It seems premature without knowing those details before making such a commitment.

speaker: davidoberg
content: Okay. To address Katrina's concern, I'd love to request that administration provide us with some preliminary thoughts on possible budgetary shifts that might occur. I fully appreciate wanting to avoid throwing up our hands saying "we're committed," while simultaneously crossing fingers hoping for grant monies or whatnot down the road.

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: To me, the big red flag raised when I saw this number is still being bandied about is we keep bringing up digital citizenship. That needs serious work, especially given how quickly these items will get integrated into classrooms. There should be an active effort made to engage parents. The training piece ties directly to effectiveness in teaching. Those three points hit me hard after re-reading it. Can I clarify again? Did the 50% device cost per year include some sort of ongoing software license fee tied to whatever tool sets are picked up as well? Would they stay in sync over the four years. Does the yearly total cover actual hardware replacement? Forgive me for trying to dig through the weeds here; it's been tough following it throughout different meetings

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: Thanks, Ellen, for that thought process. With regards to digital citizenship and the way our teachers are trained and the tools they use to teach digital citizenship is pretty robust in many respects. Of course, it never hurts to improve upon that.  I concur wholeheartedly with Dave and Katrina's remarks.

speaker: judyle
content: I want to chime in on the idea of reallocating resources. While I understand the importance of finding new revenue streams, I'm concerned that shifting existing funds away from other essential programs might cause unintended consequences. Before we consider rearranging our budget, I'd like to explore whether there are any philanthropic organizations or local businesses willing to partner with us to support this initiative. Perhaps we could establish a public-private partnership to supplement the costs. Has anyone looked into this possibility?

speaker: kateacuff
content: Thank you, Judy. Philanthropy is certainly worth exploring. If there were corporate sponsors interested in supporting our education system, it would definitely be beneficial. We should encourage administration to reach out to community leaders to gauge their willingness to contribute.

speaker: ellenosborne
content: I'd like to piggyback off of Judy's comment about exploring philanthropic opportunities. I recall attending a conference last year where a presenter discussed the success of their district's educational foundation. They had established a non-profit organization specifically designed to raise funds for initiatives like ours. Maybe we could investigate creating something similar to support our own efforts. It couldn't hurt to have another avenue for securing resources.

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: I can see both sides of this debate, folks. Realistically, we've got quite a few competing interests right now for dollars, but if we feel strongly enough about this, as others pointed out, perhaps we do take that leap of faith knowing we'll somehow cobble together enough partners and financial backing down the line. In a perfect world, sure, philanthropic groups step up, help mitigate expenses, or at least assist in covering software licenses, etcetera. But even with those hypothetical extra contributions, realistically, it won't change much. Then again, if we hold onto every single penny tightly, it may end up biting us in the future. It feels a bit of a catch-22 to me currently.

speaker: davidoberg
content: You know, my gut feeling tells me it's unrealistic to bank entirely on grants coming through, simply because they can be unpredictable and subject to various whims. Instead, I propose we focus on finding ways to make room in our budget by adjusting our spending priorities.

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: And then secondly, as Katrina brought up, how about parent involvement? I am really intrigued about the notion of setting up workshops for them. As a lot of technology is integrated into schools nowadays, having parental buy-in can prove invaluable, especially since they too must guide kids' online activities outside of class time.  I very much agree that the two needn't necessarily be mutually exclusive options. Both avenues deserve exploration.  I sense that we all genuinely wish to find creative solutions. Let's continue hashing things out further.

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: In principle, that sounds like a fine approach. At first blush, though, isn't the million-dollar question how you shift current spending and not negatively impact core programming that matters just as much? Sooner rather than later, we should receive guidance from Dr. Ziegler regarding which areas would allow us flexibility in reallocation and where the pain points are likely to arise. Are we prepared to scale back certain projects in order to make room in the budget? If so, I think we should set expectations with our constituents clearly outlining our choices ahead of time.

speaker: judyle
content: I completely agree with Katrina's concerns about potential trade-offs. If we decide to reallocate funds, we owe it to our students, staff, and community to communicate those decisions transparently. I'd like to suggest scheduling a special meeting to discuss potential budget adjustments and gather input from stakeholders before making any final decisions. By doing so, we ensure everyone involved understands the reasoning behind our choices and has a chance to weigh in. What does the rest of the board think about holding such a meeting?

speaker: kateacuff
content: I don't know why we wouldn't schedule a follow-up meeting dedicated to budget discussions and gathering input. As Judy said, transparency is key during times of fiscal constraints.

speaker: ellenosborne
content: I appreciate Katrina's pragmatism and Judy's emphasis on transparency. Holding a special meeting to discuss potential budget adjustments makes complete sense. Not only will it provide an opportunity for stakeholders to offer input, but it will also give us a clearer understanding of what our constituents value most. I fully support scheduling this meeting and believe it's crucial we involve Dr. Ziegler in these discussions to get her insight on possible areas of reallocation.

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: In addition to considering alternatives like reprioritizing existing funding sources or seeking private partnerships, one thing jumped out at me - Kate mentioned early on: cost sharing between households. I believe that warrants deeper examination, seeing how many families choose dual enrollment as part of their children's academic path already. Could we reasonably split some of those expenditures with parents who are taking advantage of dual-enrollment classes, ensuring fairness while allowing more students access without breaking the bank? This way, we're still keeping within means while maximizing our dollar usage. Does anyone have thoughts on that direction?

speaker: davidoberg
content: I do think cost-sharing models deserve attention, Katrina, particularly given the growing popularity of dual-enrollment programs. However, it strikes me as overly simplistic when juxtaposed against other possibilities we've tossed around today. With regards to prioritization and potentially scaling back less essential programs, let's remember that ultimately, we will still have to address core curriculum needs in math and science. The moment we start charging families for course access, equity issues come into play. Have we considered the long-term implications and potential legal hurdles tied to unequal treatment across socio-economic lines?

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: For the sake of clarity, Mr. Oberg seems to have hit upon an incredibly valid concern there.  To create more equal footing, how about implementing sliding-scale fees based upon household income levels? It takes account of your point, David, addressing the inherent inequality issue in charging flat rates while avoiding an uneven distribution of costs. We definitely require careful consideration going forward; however, I'm unsure whether we truly grasp the intricacies well enough yet. That said, incorporating a model of shared responsibility might bring relief and promote further accessibility despite its shortcomings.

speaker: davidoberg
content: One can hardly argue with the logic of tiered pricing arrangements designed to alleviate economic burdens placed upon lower-income households. Sliding scales could certainly be a viable compromise – though, frankly, the devil lies in its implementation details. It becomes imperative for administration to develop clear criteria defining income brackets and associated fee structures to avoid creating unintended consequences. How would this model affect middle-class families caught somewhere in between? Would assistance be offered exclusively to low-income students, leaving moderate earners vulnerable to increased financial strain? Before greenlighting such measures, we should deliberate over potential repercussions thoroughly.

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: Additionally, as Katrina mentioned earlier, how about getting parents involved?  The idea of hosting workshops really resonated with me. A lot of technology is being incorporated into classrooms lately, and having parental cooperation could help greatly, especially because they need to guide kids' use of digital resources even outside of school hours. I actually see both ideas complementing each other quite effectively, and I genuinely believe that all of us here want to discover novel solutions. Why not keep exploring both paths further?

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: Jon Noah, thank you for reiterating that valuable thought. It brings me right back to my initial proposal concerning parental engagement and digital literacy training sessions. They seem to go hand in hand with everything discussed today. If we were able to establish such initiatives and facilitate better home-school collaboration, it could result in higher productivity, even if dual-enrolled kids did indeed share in the expense through sliding scale fees or whatever method we settle on. Parents and educators working together to optimize student outcomes has always been vital to our mission.

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: If cost sharing seems inevitable and dual-enrollment classes remain popular among families, perhaps establishing workshops to empower parents digitally, then subsequently involving them in overseeing student progress may serve as an ideal hybrid solution to all parties concerned. Parental involvement holds great promise in optimizing resource allocation and mitigating budgetary challenges simultaneously.

speaker: grahampaige
content: Ok, that's enough, we will now vote privately.  We are voting on Agenda Item No. 3.3: Should the board approve the technology plan to provide Chromebooks to all high school students at an estimated annual cost of $10,000?.  If each of you could please record your vote in the chat, I will tally them up and announce the results.

speaker: kateacuff
content: abstain

speaker: ellenosborne
content: no

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: yes

speaker: davidoberg
content: no

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: no

speaker: judyle
content: abstain

content: 0 votes recorded so far.
